is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mo is="true">-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b exhibits the charge–discharge curves of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA with obvious discharge platforms at 1.94, 1.0, 0.71, 0.38&nbsp;V and charge platforms at 1.51, 1.73, 2.08&nbsp;V, which are well consistent with the CV curves. The initial discharge/charge capacities of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA are 672.4/503.9 mAh/g with an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 75.6&nbsp;%, which is higher than some previous reports <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. A clear upward trend is evident in the cycling stability of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA with a specific capacity of 533.6 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 0.2 A/g, illustrating its excellent cycle stability (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c). The MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA delivers average discharge capacities of 426.3, 423.1, 416.1, 409.5, 406.6 mAh/g at the different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 A/g, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). It is interesting that the specific capacity of 427.1 mAh/g can be obtained when the rate is returned back to 0.2 A/g. Moreover, the specific capacity at low rates of 0.1 and 0.2 A/g is nearly equal to the high rate of 2 A/g. All these results demonstrate the excellent rate capability of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e displays the cycling performance of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA electrode at the high rate of 1 A/g. It can be seen that the specific capacity of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA remains around 444.8 mAh/g even after 1000 cycles at 1 A/g, further confirming its excellent sodium storage capability. It should be noted that the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA electrode also exhibited the outstanding sodium storage performance compared to other previous reports (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>. The superior sodium storage capability could attribute to the bimetallic selenide heterostructure which improve the reaction kinetic and promote sodium ions diffusion <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. In addition, the synergistic effect between unique structure (porous octahedron), and GA was beneficial for alleviate volume expansion and prevent rapid capacity decay <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">We further investigated the capacitive behaviors of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA by the CV measurement at different scan rates. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f, the CV profiles display similar shapes at different scan rates from 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. The mean <em>b</em>-value for the reduction–oxidation peaks was calculated to be 0.88, indicating a pseudocapacitive effect and fast kinetics (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g) (Text S1) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. The light green area shows the contribution of the pseudocapacitive behavior with a calculated ratio of 74.5&nbsp;% at a sweep rate of 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>h). The pseudocapacitive contributions are 56.69&nbsp;%, 57.89&nbsp;%, 74.51&nbsp;%, 83.56&nbsp;%, and 88.71&nbsp;% at different scan rates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i). With the increase of scan rates, the pseudocapacitive contribution gradually increases, demonstrating the rapid kinetics of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA at high current density. Based on these results, it is clear that the pseudocapacitive charge storage occupies a high percentage of the total capacity.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a shows the CV curves for CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA with some obvious irreversible peaks at 0.19, 0.34, and 1.04&nbsp;V associated with SEI films <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. Na<sub>x</sub>MnSe is formed and then converted to Na<sub>2</sub>Se and Mn, resulting in two peaks at 1.50 and 0.72&nbsp;V, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. Additionally, the reduction peak at 1.50&nbsp;V is related to the insertion of CoSe<sub>2</sub> with Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a><span>. For the anodic scan, the two <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> peaks at 1.50 and 1.84&nbsp;V are caused by the desodification process and the formation of CoSe</span><sub>2</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>. In addition, a weak peak at 2.04&nbsp;V is assigned to the formation of MnSe <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. The CV curves of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA overlapped well in subsequent discharge–charge cycles, indicating its good stabilization as anodes for SIBs. The chemical reactions of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA are summarized as follows (Equs. 10–18):</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr5.jpg" height="459" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (619KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (619KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Na-ion storage performances of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA in a voltage range of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V (vs. Na<sup>+</sup><span>/Na): (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the first four cycles at 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>−1</sup>; (b) Charge-discharge profiles at 0.2 A/g; (c) Cycling stability at 0.2 A/g; (d) Rate capabilities from 0.1 A/g to 2.0 A/g; (e) Cycling stability at a high rate of 1 A/g; (f) CV curves at different scan rates (from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>); (g) Plots of log (scan rate) vs log (peak current), calculated from CV curves; (h) Capacity contribution ratios at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>; (i) Contribution ratios between diffusion controlled and capacitive capacity.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">The discharge reaction:<span class="display"><span id="e0050" class="formula"><span class="label">(10)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-28-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xlink:href="#MJMAIN-65"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2224,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8858,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(9859,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-78"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1279,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1779,410)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(12511,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(13512,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-78"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-65"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(973,362)"><g is="true"><use is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true"></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">x</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">o</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">→</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">-</mo><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b exhibits the charge/discharge curves of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA, corresponding to the plateau of the CV curves. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c, the specific capacity delivered by CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA is about 456.7 mAh/g at 0.2 A/g after 100 cycles, which is slightly lower than that of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA. The CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA delivers a specific capacity of 470.6, 457.1, 439.9, 425.4, 406.6, 460.9 mAh/g at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 0.2 A/g, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d). And the specific capacity of the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA electrode remains at 442.9 mAh/g at 1 A/g after 1000 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e). A similar pseudocapacitive test was carried out for CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA and the calculated b-value was approximately 0.87 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f and g, Text S1). And the corresponding capacitive contributions are 54.57&nbsp;%, 56.47&nbsp;%, 73.54&nbsp;%, 82.35&nbsp;%, and 88.03&nbsp;% at the scan rates of 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, belonging to the pseudocapacitive contribution (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h and i). It is interesting that the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA electrode also exhibits outstanding sodium storage compared to other previous reports (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">The first four CV curves for NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA are also exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a. The first CV cycle is inconsistent with the subsequent three cycles, which might be related to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of the SEI film. In the initial cycle, two irreversible peaks occur at around 0.33&nbsp;V and 1.27&nbsp;V, which could be ascribed to the generation of the SEI layer and the disposable sodium storage point <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>. The additional reduction peaks are all associated with the insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> and the production of Na<sub>2</sub>Se, Zn, and Ni <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. In contrast, the generation of oxidation peaks corresponds to the removal of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. The first discharge/charge capacity of the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA is 736.8/491.9 mAh/g with an initial coulombic efficiency of 66.8&nbsp;%. After 50th cycle, the discharge/charge capacity is 242.1/236.8 mAh/g with the coulombic efficiency of 97.8&nbsp;%. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c exhibits the cycling performance of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA at 0.2 A/g, where a specific capacity of 302.2 mAh/g could be obtained after 100 cycles. The NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA delivers specific capacities of 285.8, 237.7, 206.0, 180.1, 171.1, 203.1 mAh/g at different current densities from 0.1 to 2.0 A/g, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d). While the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA only deliver a specific capacity of 190.5 mAh/g at a high current of 1 A/g after 1000 cycles, which is much lower than that of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA and CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e). The average b-value of the six redox peaks for the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA is about 0.58 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>f and g), being different from MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA and CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA. The capacitive contributions are 48.78&nbsp;%, 52.03&nbsp;%, 69.39&nbsp;%, 79.07&nbsp;%, and 85.48&nbsp;% at the different scan rates of 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>h and i). It was found that the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA electrode exhibits a lower pseudocapacitance contribution compared to the other two samples, indicating a slower transport rate and kinetic response. To further investigate the good cycling performances of the active materials, we further characterized the thickness of the electrode sheet (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>a–f show the thickness of the electrode sheets before and after cycling. It can be noticed that the electrode sheets all have undergone different degrees of expansion. The expansion thickness of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA (2.5&nbsp;μm) and CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA (3.8&nbsp;μm) is much lower than that of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA (9.7&nbsp;μm), confirming the excellent electrochemical properties of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA and CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr6.jpg" height="580" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (826KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (826KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Na-ion storage performances of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA in the voltage range of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V (vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na): (a) CV curves of the first four cycles at 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>; (b) Charge-discharge profiles at 0.2 A/g; (c) Cycling stability at 0.2 A/g; (d) Rate capabilities from 0.1 to 2.0 A/g; (e) Cycling stability at high rate of 1 A/g; (f) CV curves at different scan rates (from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>); (g) Plots of log (scan rate) vs log (peak current), calculated from CV curves; (h) Capacity contribution ratios at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>; (i) Contribution ratios between diffusion controlled and capacitive capacity.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) measurements were used to analyze the kinetic differences between the different electrodes. All Nyquist plots in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>a exhibit a depressed semicircle and a descending line in the high and low frequency regions, corresponding to the charge transfer resistance (Rct) and Warburg impedance (Wo), respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>b shows the Randall-type equivalent circuit model, and the results are presented in Tab. S2. The Nyquist plots show that the impedance of these samples is in a clear sequence of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA, corresponding to the R<sub>ct</sub><span> of 6.23, 33.55, and 40.33&nbsp;Ω, respectively. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrical-impedance" title="Learn more about Electrical impedance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrical impedance</a> measurements further demonstrate that the highest capacity of MoSe</span><sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA with a special porous octahedron is related to its lower impedance and rapid reaction kinetics. This result is also consistent with the excellent rate capability of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA since the charge transfer process is the rate-determining step for sodium ion storage.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">In summary, we have developed three types of heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within GA via a simple MOF-derived selenide strategy. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites exhibit special structural features, such as porous octahedron, cubes, or spheres, which can shorten the migration path for Na<sup>+</sup>/electrons and accommodate the volume variations of the metal selenides via additional void space during cycling. GA can not only keep the structural integrity of the active material during cycling, but also improve the conductivity of the electrode, resulting in the enhancement electrochemical property. The built-in electric fields at the heterointerfaces can enhance reaction kinetics and promote the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup>/electrons. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA with a porous octahedron delivers the highest capacity of 444.8 mAh/g at a high current rate of 1 A/g after 1000 cycles. It should be noted that the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA electrode also exhibits outstanding sodium storage and cycle performances, even compared to other previous reports <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>. This work could provide a possible universal method for constructing a bimetallic selenide/GA with homogeneous microstructure as anodes for the next-generation SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0045"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120"><strong>Hao Tian:</strong> Writing – original draft, Validation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Zhengzheng Xu:</strong> Writing – original draft, Methodology, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Kun Liu:</strong> Software, Formal analysis. <strong>Dong Wang:</strong> Software, Methodology, Data curation. <strong>Lulin Ren:</strong> Validation, Software. <strong>Yumeng Wei:</strong> Visualization, Methodology. <strong>Lizhuang Chen:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Yingying Chen:</strong> Validation, Methodology. <strong>Shanhu Liu:</strong> Software, Resources, Formal analysis. <strong>Hongxun Yang:</strong> .</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">This work was financially supported by the Foundation from Jiangsu Province Industry-University-Research Collaboration (BY20231163, BY20231179), and the Modern Agricultural Projects of Zhenjiang (NY2019022).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0055"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Lin</div><div id="ref-id-h0025" class="title text-m">Construction of unique heterogeneous cobalt-manganese oxide porous microspheres for the assembly of long-cycle and high-rate lithium ion battery anodes</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Mater. Chem. class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (13)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724024123"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Tannic acid etching construction of hollow heterogeneous CoSe&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;-FeSe&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;@nitrogen-doped carbon rhombic dodecahedron for high-performance sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Metal selenides are very promising anode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their rich redox behaviors, low cost, high theoretical capacity, and environmentally benign. However, the poor cycle performance and rate capability greatly hinder their widespread applications. In this paper, we have proposed a tannic acid etching zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67)-derived selenide strategy to construct hollow heterogeneous CoSe<sub>2</sub>-FeSe<sub>2</sub>@<em>N</em>-doped carbon rhombic dodecahedron (CoSe<sub>2</sub>-FeSe<sub>2</sub>@NC) as anode for high-performance SIBs. The special microstructural characteristics with hollow rhombic dodecahedron can reduce the Na<sup>+</sup>/electron migration path and alleviate the volume variations during cycling. The NC can improve conductivity and reduce volume effects during cycling. What’s more, the built-in electric fields (BIEF) at the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-FeSe<sub>2</sub> heterointerfaces can modulate the electronic structure and accelerate the kinetics of ionic diffusion, resulting in the improvement electrochemical properties. When applied as anodes for SIBs, the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-FeSe<sub>2</sub>@NC can deliver a remarkable electrochemical performance in terms of sodium storage capacity (648.5&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;A/g), initial coulombic efficiency (82.0&nbsp;%), cycle performance (92.6&nbsp;% capacity retention after 100 cycles), and rate capability of 450.6&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 1000 cycles at a high rate of 1&nbsp;A/g. The kinetic analysis indicates that the discharging-charging process of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-FeSe<sub>2</sub>@NC is ascribed to both capacitive behavior and controlled diffusion.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925963524011075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A new soft-hard carbon composite derived from petroleum coke and glucose for high-performance sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Diamond and Related Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0030">Hard carbon is an ideal material for negative electrodes in sodium ion batteries, but it still has drawbacks such as high cost and poor conductivity. In contrast, soft carbon behaves the low acquisition cost and graphitization at high temperatures, which is beneficial for improving the performance of sodium ion batteries (SIBs). Herein, we have developed a new soft-hard carbon composite (PCGLU) using petroleum coke (PC) and glucose as (GLU) raw materials prepared through ball milling reaction and subsequent calcination technology. This PCGLU behaves the advantages of hard carbon and soft carbon, larger interlayer spacing, and porous structure, which could increase the active sites of Na<sup>+</sup>, which could increase the active sites of Na<sup>+</sup>, shorten the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion distance, and promote the penetration of electrolytes. As an anode for sodium-ion batteries, the PCGLU carbonization at 800&nbsp;°C (PCGLU-800) with suitable graphite layer spacing (0.358&nbsp;nm) can provide a specific capacity of 255.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at a rate of 25 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100&nbsp;cycles. Even at a high current density of 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the PCGLU-800 can still deliver a capacity of 170.7 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 1000&nbsp;cycles. This study could provide a simple possible method for preparing high-performance soft-hard carbon electrode materials for SIBs, and the design strategy can be generalized to other biomass-based soft-hard carbon materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S138589472409380X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Ni&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;P/Cu&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;P bimetallic phosphide embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon as SIB anode: Constructed hetero interface promoting fast Na&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; diffusion and storage performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have attracted widespread attention as electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical specific capacity, various bonding types, metallic characteristics, and low cost. However, their sluggish reaction kinetics and inferior capacity decay severely hamper their application. Designing TMPs with novel nano/microstructures effectively overcomes these challenges. Herein, Nickel Phosphide/Copper Phosphide embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon (Ni<sub>2</sub>P/Cu<sub>3</sub>P@NC) was synthesized by carbonization and phosphidation process. When used as an SIB anode, Ni<sub>2</sub>P/Cu<sub>3</sub>P@NC exhibited a reversible specific capacity of 530&nbsp;mAh/g after 200 cycles at 0.2 A/g, 428&nbsp;mAh/g after 1000 cycles at 1.0 A/g, and good rate capability (334&nbsp;mAh/g at 2.0 A/g). Ex-situ XRD combined with in-situ EIS confirm the irreversible conversion mechanism. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations show that the heterointerface formed between Ni<sub>2</sub>P and Cu<sub>3</sub>P serves as a channel for fast ion delivery and promotes Na<sup>+</sup> storage performance. Furthermore, the practical application was further investigated by assembling Ni<sub>2</sub>P/Cu<sub>3</sub>P@NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> full cells.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24032687"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">N/P/O co-doped porous carbon derived from agroindustry waste of peanut shell for sodium-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Therefore, it is very urgent to develop new anode materials with satisfied sodium storage capacity for the large-scale application of SIBs. Currently, three kinds of anode materials for SIBs have been widely studied and reported, including: (i) carbonaceous materials (soft carbon, graphene, hard carbon) mainly via intercalation mechanisms [15–18]; (ii) main group metal (such as Sn, Sb, Bi) utilising alloy-conversion mechanisms [19–21]; (iii) metallides (sulphides, selenide, nitrides) based on conversion reaction mechanisms [22–25]. Among these materials, carbon-based materials are of very interest for their stable structure, low environmental pollution, low cost, excellent electrical conductivity, and high sodium storage capacity [26].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0040">Porous bio‑carbon from agroindustry waste behaves one of the most promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) because of its high sodium storage capacity, low cost, sustainability, and low charge/discharge voltage platform. Herein, we have developed a new N/P/O co-doped porous hard carbon derived from peanut shell (PSCNP) synthesized via KOH activation, hydrothermal doping combined with carbonization method, using chitosan as nitrogen source, phytic acid as phosphorus source, and peanut shell as carbon and oxygen source. Through seriously regulating the calcination temperature, the optimal PSCNP-800 carbonization at 800&nbsp;°C can well combine the advantages of the natural rich porous microstructure of peanut shells, large graphite interlayer spacing (0.379&nbsp;nm), and short diffusion distance for sodium-ion. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the PSCNP-800 delivered a reversible capacity of 248.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100&nbsp;cycles at 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. This work could provide a possible idea for the preparation of N/P/O co-doped porous hard carbon from low-cost agroindustry waste as anodes for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d4ta07323a" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Enhanced electrochemical performance of NiSbS/NiSb/NiS nanocomposites anchored on graphite nanosheets for sodium-ion battery applications</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny A</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d4qi01704h" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A general strategy for the in situ construction of CoSe&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;-MSe&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt;@GA (M = Zn, Ni, and Fe) heterostructures for effective sodium storage</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Inorganic Chemistry Frontiers</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724010920" title="Dendrite-free Zn anode enabled by combining carbon nanoparticles hydrophobic layer with crystal face reconstruction toward high-performance Zn-ion battery"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Dendrite-free Zn anode enabled by combining carbon nanoparticles hydrophobic layer with crystal face reconstruction toward class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article2-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979721020944" title="Ni3Se4@CoSe2 hetero-nanocrystals encapsulated into CNT-porous carbon interpenetrating frameworks for high-performance sodium ion battery"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Ni<sub>3</sub>Se<sub>4</sub>@CoSe<sub>2</sub> hetero-nanocrystals encapsulated into CNT-porous carbon interpenetrating frameworks for high-performance sodium ion battery</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, Volume 611, 2022, pp. 718-725</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Hangyi</span> <span>Zhu</span>, …, <span>Haosen</span> <span>Fan</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979721020944/pdfft?md5=59628e0ebd2883f3a7b874bf59b92ee0&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0021979721020944-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article2-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448 1.228-1.462.008-1.06-.316-1.45-1.23-1.45h-.347m-.977-.94h1.03c1.68 0 2.523.586 2.534 2.39.01 1.688-.607 2.4-2.534 2.4h-1.03V3.64m4.305 0h2.63v.934h-1.657v.894H16.6V6.4h-1.56v2.026h-.97V3.638"></path><path d="M19.462 13.46c.348 4.274-6.59 16.72-8.508 15.792-1.82-.85 1.53-3.317 2.92-4.366-2.864.894-5.394 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-none"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article3-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468622003395" title="Co0.85Se@carbon nanotubes surface-seeding grown on carbon microplates as superior anode material for sodium ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se@carbon nanotubes surface-seeding grown on carbon microplates as superior anode material for sodium ion     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {

    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',

        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

      </script>
