text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span><span>Metal <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/selenide" title="Learn more about selenides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">selenides</a><span> are promising anode candidates for <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a><span> (SIBs) because of their high theoretical capacity, low cost, and environmental friendship. However, the low rate capability at high current density due to its inherent low <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and poor cycle stability caused by inevitable volume variations during cycling frustrate its practical applications. Herein, we have developed a simple metallic-organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived selenide strategy to synthesize a series of heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within graphene </span></span></span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/aerogel" title="Learn more about aerogels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aerogels</a> (GA) as anodes for SIBs. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites have unique structural characteristics that can shorten the migration path for Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>/electrons and accommodate the volume variations via additional void space during cycling. The built-in electric fields induced at the heterointerfaces can greatly reduce the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/activation-energy" title="Learn more about activation energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation energy</a> for rapid charge transfer kinetics and promote the diffusion of Na</span><sup>+</sup>/electrons. GA is also beneficial for accommodating the volume variations during cycling and improving conductivity. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a special porous octahedron can deliver the highest capacity of 444.8 mAh/g at a high rate of 1 A/g even after 1000 cycles among the bimetallic selenides/GA composites.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (186KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (186KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724009962"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724010592"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Metal selenides</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Graphene aerogel</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Heterojunction</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Anodes</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The impact of energy shortage and environmental pollution has led to an urgent need for suitable, high-performance, and viable new energy storage units for electric vehicles, equipment, and other fields to alleviate these problems <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a><span>. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lithium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about Lithium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Lithium ion batteries</a> (LIBs) have achieved true commercial applications in a wide range of our work and daily life </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>. However, the scarce lithium resources on earth and the increasing cost of LIBs hinder their long-term and widespread applications <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a><span><span>. In contrast, <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> behaves very rich resources and much lower cost. More importantly, sodium and lithium are the same main group elements and behave similar chemical properties. Thus, </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a> (SIBs) are one of the most suitable candidates for LIBs in some fields </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>. The main bottleneck in SIBs is the search for electrode materials with excellent performance, especially the anode electrode <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a><span>. The different <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> of SIBs, such as hard carbon </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a><span>, <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, alloys <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, sulphides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, phosphides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, and selenides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a><span>, are being developed rapidly. Among these anode materials, metal selenides have become one of the most promising anodes for SIBs due to their high capacity, low cost, environmental friendliness, and rich <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. However, the drawbacks of its low rate capability and poor cycling stability due to its inherent poor conductivity and inevitable volume changes during cycling frustrate its practical applications <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">To resolve these problems, some strategies have been developed to engineer the metal selenides with stable structure and excellent electrochemical properties, such as designing unique structures, coupling with carbon-based materials, selecting upper cut-off voltages, optimizing composition <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>. Currently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with a specific morphological structure are usually used as precursors to design and synthesize metal selenides for the application of SIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a><span>. It has also been shown that the construction of metal selenide <a href="/topics/materials-science/heterojunction" title="Learn more about heterostructures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterostructures</a> is considered an innovative method for improving electrochemical properties </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>. The built-in electric fields (BIEF) existing in the heterointerfaces can reduce the activation barrier and promote reaction kinetics due to lattice distortions and electronic rearrangements <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a><span>. The porous heterogeneous composite can not only accelerate <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electric-charge" title="Learn more about electric charge from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electric charge</a><span> transfer and improve the storage of sodium ions, but also avoid structural damage caused by sodium ion intercation/deintercation. Zhang et al. prepared <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/heterojunctions" title="Learn more about heterojunction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterojunction</a> bimetallic selenide nanoboxes (SnSe</span></span><sub>2</sub>/CoSe<sub>2</sub>@C) with core–shell structures, exhibiting excellent sodium storage capacity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the combination of MOF with graphene can further improve the conductivity of the active material, as well as prevent the fragmentation of the MOF during the subsequent heat treatment process and charging/discharging cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. At present, the construction of MOF-based metal selenide heterojunction/graphene composites is limited to the random combination of single MOF and graphene aerogels (GA). And there are also some uncertain factors in the regulation of heterostructure, leading to the difficulty in precise regulation of heterostructure and the improvement of performance. The synergistic effect between heterogeneous interfaces and the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> ions at the phase boundary still remains to be studied. Therefore, it is a key challenge to construct the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides/GA and explore the effect factor on the electrochemcial properties.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><span>Herein, a series of MOF-derived heterogeneous bimetallic selenides embedded within GA were successfully developed and used as anodes for SIBs. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites exhibit special structural features, such as porous octahedron, cube, and sphere, which are benefit for the efficient and rapid transport of sodium ions within the electrodes. Furthermore, the built-in electric fields induced at the heterointerfaces can also greatly reduce the reaction <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/activation-energy" title="Learn more about activation energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation energy</a> and promote fast reaction kinetics. Last but not the least, GA as an external carrier can not only maintain the structural integrity of the active material, but also improve the overall electronic conductivity. Benefitting from these advantages, the resulting MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a special porous octahedron indicates super sodium storage performance with high-capacity and fast kinetics. When used as an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA can deliver exceptional rate capability (406.6 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 2 A g<sup>−1</sup>) and high reversible capacities (533.6 mAh/g at 0.2 A/g after 100 cycles and 444.8 mAh/g at 1 A/g even after 1000 cycles). This work could provide a possible universal method for constructing a bimetallic selenide/GA composite as an advanced anode for next-generation SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Cupric acetate (Cu<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>4</sub>), phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>·12MoO<sub>3</sub>·xH<sub>2</sub>O), manganese acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub><span><span>O), <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a> cyanide </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/iridium" title="Learn more about iridium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">iridium</a> (K</span><sub>3</sub>[Co(CN)<sub>6</sub>]), zinc sulfate heptahydrate (ZnSO<sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O), and potassium tetracyanonickelate hydrate (K<sub>3</sub>[Ni(CN)<sub>4</sub>]·xH<sub>2</sub>O) were purchased from China Pharmaceutical Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. <span class="small-caps">l</span>-glutamic acid (C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>9</sub>NO<sub>4</sub>, 99.9&nbsp;%), trimesic acid (C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>6</sub>, 99.9&nbsp;%), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, K-30, 99.9&nbsp;%), and selenium (Se, 99.9&nbsp;%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals and solvents were used directly without further purification.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Sample preparations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><strong>Preparation of Mo-Cu-MOF:</strong> Typically, 0.1996&nbsp;g of cupric acetate, 0.0735&nbsp;g of <span class="small-caps">l</span>-glutamic acid and 0.3686&nbsp;g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate were added into 40&nbsp;mL of water to form solution A. 0.138&nbsp;g of trimesic acid was added into 40&nbsp;mL of ethanol to form solution B. Then, solution B was dropped into solution A at a speed of 5&nbsp;mL&nbsp;min<sup>−1</sup> using a peristaltic pump under continuous stirring for 24&nbsp;h at room temperature. The precipitate was centrifuged, washed three times by distilled water and ethanol, and was then dried in a vacuum oven to obtain the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><strong>Preparation of Co-Mn-MOF:</strong> Typically, 0.276&nbsp;g of Mn(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O and 1&nbsp;g of polyvinylpyrrolidone were added into 60&nbsp;mL of ethanol to produce solution A, and 0.1995&nbsp;g of K<sub>3</sub>[Co(CN)<sub>6</sub>] was added into 60&nbsp;mL of water to produce solution B. Solution B was dropped into solution A at a speed of 5&nbsp;mL&nbsp;min<sup>−1</sup> using a peristaltic pump under continuous stirring for 24&nbsp;h at room temperature. The precipitate was then centrifuged, washed three times with distilled water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven to obtain the Co-Mn-MOF precursor.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><strong>Preparation of Ni-Zn-MOF:</strong> Typically, 0.24&nbsp;g of ZnSO<sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O and 0.45&nbsp;g of polyvinylpyrrolidone were dispersed in 50&nbsp;mL of water to form a clear solution. Separately, 0.2&nbsp;g of K<sub>3</sub>[Ni(CN)<sub>4</sub>]·xH<sub>2</sub>O was dissolved in 50&nbsp;mL of water under magnetic stirring to form another clear solution. Subsequently, the two solution were combined to form a suspension, which was magnetically stirred for 24&nbsp;h at room temperature. After that, a precipitate was centrifuged, washed with distilled water and ethanol for three times, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80&nbsp;°C to obtain the Ni-Zn-MOF precursor.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><strong>Preparation of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.8</sub>Se@GA:</strong><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about Graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Graphene oxide</a> (GO) was obtained using an improved Hummers method </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>. 0.2&nbsp;g of Mo-Cu-MOF was added into an aqueous dispersion of graphene oxide (GO) (1.5&nbsp;mg&nbsp;mL<sup>−1</sup>, 30&nbsp;mL) with vigorous stirring to form Mo-Cu-MOF@GO composite for 24&nbsp;h at room temperature. Then, the composite was further freeze-dried overnight to obtain Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel. 0.2&nbsp;g of Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel was mixed with 0.4&nbsp;g of Se powder and kept at 450&nbsp;°C for 2&nbsp;h with a ramp rate of 2&nbsp;°C·min<sup>−1</sup> in 5&nbsp;% H<sub>2</sub>/Ar atmosphere to get MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@graphene aerogel (MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA). In the same way, CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA and NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA were obtained under similar conditions.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Material characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>X-ray diffractometry (XRD) data of the as-obtained products were collected on a Shimadzu 6000 <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a><span><span> equipped with graphite monochromatized CuKα radiation flux. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was measured by scanning <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a> (Carl Zeiss Supra 40). </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about Transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Transmission electron microscopy</a><span> (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping analysis were taken with JEM-2100 (JEOL Co., Japan) microscope. The surface composition and the valence state of the products were performed by Thermo ESCALAB 250XI. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> were measured by a Renishaw InVia instrument with a He-Ne laser (532&nbsp;nm) excitation source at a resolution of 1&nbsp;cm</span></span></span><sup>−1</sup>.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">Electrochemical measurements of the as-synthesized samples were performed using CR2032 half-cells with Na sheet as counter electrode and Whatman GF/D as separator. The active materials were mixed with Super P and PVDF at a mass ratio of 70:20:10 and ground into a slurry with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurry was then poured onto the copper foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 70&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. The area mass was loaded at approximately 1.2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>−2</sup>. The electrolyte for the CR2032 half-cells was 1&nbsp;M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in dimethyl ether. Cell assembly was performed in an argon filled glove box (O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.1&nbsp;ppm, H<sub>2</sub>O&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.1&nbsp;ppm). Electrostatic charge/discharge tests were performed using a LAND CT-2001A battery tester at various current densities within a cut-off voltage range of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V (vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760 E, Chenhua Ltd. Co., China) with a scan speed of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup><span>, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) tests were obtained using an electrochemical workstation (Autolab PGSTAT 302&nbsp;N) with an amplitude of 5&nbsp;mV and a frequency range of 100&nbsp;kHz to 0.1&nbsp;Hz.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scheme 1</span></span></a> illustrates the fabrication process of the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within GA. The morphologies and microstructures of the as-obtained products were investigated by SEM and TEM. As seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a, the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor reveals a smooth octahedral structure with a diameter of 1&nbsp;μm or so. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b shows the SEM image of the Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel. It can be found that the Mo-Cu-MOF still retains original octahedral structure after wrapping with GO. The SEM image of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c clearly confirms the existence of GA and MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span>Se with the diameter of 900&nbsp;nm or so, which is smaller than that of the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor. It is interesting that during the selenization process some octahedra are converted into small <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a><span> to form secondary <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocrystalline-material" title="Learn more about nanomaterials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanomaterials</a>. It is more beneficial to increase the contact areas between the active material and electrolyte, and shorten the transport channel of Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span>, thereby resulting in the improvement of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage performance. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d exhibits the SEM images of Co-Mn-MOF precursor. It can be obviously seen that the Co-Mn-MOF consists of cubic particles with a diameter of 1&nbsp;μm or so, which is different from the Mo-Cu-MOF. The Co-Mn-MOF are further combined with GO to obtain Co-Mn-MOF@GO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>f displays the SEM images of CoSe<sub>2</sub><span>-MnSe@GA, clearly showing the homogeneous shape of the cubes with a diameter of 900&nbsp;nm or so wrapped with GA. While the Ni-Zn-MOF precursor behaves as uniform <a href="/topics/materials-science/microsphere" title="Learn more about microspheres from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microspheres</a> with a diameter of about 500&nbsp;nm. The Ni-Zn-MOF@GO also shows a homogeneous spherical shape wrapped among GO (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>h). Close observation of the morphology by high magnification SEM reveals that the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe microspheres are all uniformly wrapped within a layer of graphene, and that high-temperature selenisation does not produce morphological fragments (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>i). The aerogel networks formed by GA can effectively avoid the powder agglomeration and volume expansion during the high temperature selenisation process. The addition of GA is sure help to synthesize the heterogeneous bimetallic selenide composite.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr7.jpg" height="294" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (305KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (305KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Scheme 1</span>. Schematic illustration for the fabrication process of bimetallic <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/selenide" title="Learn more about selenides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">selenides</a> encapsulated within graphene aerogel.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr1.jpg" height="721" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (417KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (417KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. SEM images: (a) Mo-Cu-MOF, (b) Mo-Cu-MOF@GO, (c) MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA, (d) Co-Mn-MOF, (e) Co-Mn-MOF@GO, (f) CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA, (g) Ni-Zn-MOF, (h) Ni-Zn-MOF@GO, (i) NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">The structural features of the bimetallic selenide@GA composites were further investigated by TEM and HRTEM. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a exhibits the TEM images of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA with the diameter of 900&nbsp;nm or so, which is consistent with the SEM images. It can be clearly seen that the rough octahedral structure is surrounded by thin layers of graphene sheets. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b, an interplanar crystal spacing of 0.20&nbsp;nm correlates to the crystal plane of Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se, and another interplanar crystal spacing of 0.19&nbsp;nm corresponds to the crystal plane of MoSe<sub>2</sub>. From the HRTEM of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA, it can be also seen that there are apparent heterogeneous interfaces between MoSe<sub>2</sub> and Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span>Se. The heterogeneous interfaces can cause uneven charge distribution on different crystal faces and form potential difference, thus inducing built-in electric fields. The built-in electric fields can reduce the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/activation-energy" title="Learn more about activation energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation energy</a>, accelerate the transfer of sodium ions, and promote Na</span><sup>+</sup>/electrons separation and diffusion, resulting in the improvement of sodium ion storage during the charge/discharge process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. It is interesting that the distinct boundary between MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se and GA could be also found in the HRTEM images of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span><span>b, helping to the improvement of <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a>. In the selected area </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) image presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c, the diffraction rings of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA correspond to (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;2) lattice planes of Cu<sub>1.8</sub>Se and (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;6), (3&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) lattice planes of MoSe<sub>2</sub>, respectively. For the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d), the CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe cubic particles with the diameter of 900&nbsp;nm or so are embedded between graphene sheets, which is similar to the SEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>i). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e exhibits the TEM images of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA. It is obviously seen that the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA microspheres are also wrapped within graphene sheets. The clear visibility of the atomic stripes in the HRTEM image strongly suggests that the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA is highly crystalline (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f). The atomic lattice stripe with a distance of 0.31&nbsp;nm corresponds to (0&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) plane of cubic NiSe<sub>2</sub>, while the lattice spacing of 0.20&nbsp;nm is represented by the (2&nbsp;2&nbsp;0) plane of ZnSe. It should be noted that there are also bimetallic heterogeneous interfaces in the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA which can generate built-in electric fields <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g shows the EDX mapping images of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA. The elemental mapping photos show the homogeneous distributions of C, Mo, Se, and Cu elements in the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA hybrid.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr2.jpg" height="635" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a, b) Low and high-resolution <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> of MoSe</span><sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span>Se@GA; (c) <a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about Selected area electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Selected area electron diffraction</a> (SAED) of MoSe</span><sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span>Se@GA; (d) <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> of CoSe</span><sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA; (e, f) Low and HRTEM of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA; (g) EDX elemental mapping for C, Mo, Se, Cu of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">The XRD patterns of the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a, which clearly reveals the combination of MoSe<sub>2</sub> (JCPDS card no. 04-005-6604), Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se (JCPDS card no. 04-002-6190), and GA. Specifically, the characteristic peaks of 31.3°, 37.8°, 47.4°, 53.2° and 55.8° correspond to the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;0), (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;3), (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;5), (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;6) and (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0) crystal face of MoSe<sub>2</sub>, while the peak at 44.7° represents the crystal face (2&nbsp;2&nbsp;0) of Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se. The Raman spectrum of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA is exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b. The intensity ratio of I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span> can be used to determine the degree of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> of carbon materials. The MoSe</span><sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA exhibits a peak intensity ratio (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub>) of 0.7 or so, indicating its lower graphitization degree. The XPS survey spectrum confirms that the elements of Mo, Cu, Se, C, and O are present in the MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d displays the XPS spectrum of Mo3d with two obvious peaks at 232.2&nbsp;eV and 229.9&nbsp;eV, which are ascribed to Mo 3d<sub>3/2</sub> and Mo 3d<sub>5/2,</sub> respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>. The narrow peaks at 952.7&nbsp;eV and 933.8&nbsp;eV can be detected from the Cu2p XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e), which correspond to the signals of Cu 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Cu 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively. Furthermore, two shake-up satellite peaks can also be observed at 934.6 and 943.1&nbsp;eV of Cu 2p <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>. According to <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f, the peaks in the Se 3d spectrum located at 55.1 and 54.4&nbsp;eV are attributed to the Se 3d<sub>3/2</sub> and Se 3d<sub>5/2</sub> binding energies, whereas the signal at 59.3&nbsp;eV corresponds to the Se-O binding energy <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. The XRD patterns of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA are consistent with the standard JCPDS card No. 03-065-3327 for CoSe<sub>2</sub> and JCPDS card 04-004-6054 for MnSe (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a). In addition, the Raman spectrum of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA shows an intensity ratio (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub>) of around 0.83, which is slightly higher than that of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>b). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>c–f exhibit the XPS spectrum of CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA. Based on the XPS survey spectrum, it is evident that the Mn, Co, Se, O, and C are present (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>c). As seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>d, the Co 2p spectrum shows five peaks. The peaks located at 781.3 and 797.5&nbsp;eV are ascribed to Co 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Co 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, implying the presence of Co<sup>2+</sup> in CoSe<sub>2</sub>-MnSe@GA <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. In contrast, the peaks at 778.8 and 793.2&nbsp;eV correspond to Co 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. And the peaks at 654.0 and 641.8&nbsp;eV are ascribed to Mn 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Mn 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>e) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>f shows three peaks at 55.7, 56.6, and 59.5&nbsp;eV, corresponding to Se 3d<sub>5/2</sub>, Se 3d<sub>3/2</sub>, and SeO<sub>x</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. The XRD pattern of NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA clearly shows a good match to NiSe<sub>2</sub> (JCPDS card 04-003-4305) and ZnSe (JCPDS card 04-001-7280) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>a). The Raman spectrum of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA behaves an intensity ratio (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub>) of 0.72 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>b). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>c–f exhibit the NiSe<sub>2</sub>-ZnSe@GA XPS pattern. Spectrum analysis of Zn 2p at high resolution confirms the presence of Zn 2p<sub>3/2</sub> at 1022.4&nbsp;eV and Zn 2p<sub>1/2</sub> at 1045.4&nbsp;eV (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>d) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. The Ni 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Ni 2p<sub>1/2</sub> are responsible for the peaks at 855.5 and 873.6&nbsp;eV, and the satellite peaks are responsible for two other weak peaks (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>e) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. The peaks at 55.1 and 56.1&nbsp;eV reflect the presence of Se 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and 3d<sub>3/2</sub><span>, respectively, and the board peak at 58.9&nbsp;eV indicates its high <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> state (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0055" name="bs0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>f) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. These above characterizations, including SEM, TEM, EDX, XRD, Raman and XPS, further demonstrate that the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides are well encapsulated within GA.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr3.jpg" height="428" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (554KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (554KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Material characterizations of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span><span>Se@GA. (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction-analysis" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns; (b) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> (by repeating the experiment three times); (c) XPS survey spectrum (by repeating the experiment three times); XPS high-resolution spectrum of (d) Mo3d, (e) Cu2p, (f) Se3d.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a shows the first three CV profiles of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub><span>Se@GA. It is confirmed that the reduction peaks at 0.39 and 0.72&nbsp;V are caused by the decomposition of the electrolyte and the production of a <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> interface (SEI) film, which subsequently disappear in subsequent cycles, whereas all other reduction peaks are determined as the insertion of Na</span><sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. NaCuSe is transformed to Na<sub>x</sub>CuSe at 1.63&nbsp;V, and the subsequent desodiation from Na<sub>x</sub>CuSe results in an anodic peak at 1.93&nbsp;V <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. During the formation of Na<sub>x</sub>MoSe<sub>2</sub>, the peak at 0.67&nbsp;V is observed <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Specifically, the peak located at 1.22&nbsp;V is attributed to the conversion reaction between MoSe<sub>2</sub> and Na<sup>+</sup> that produces Mo and Na<sub>2</sub>Se <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. The intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> into Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se and MoSe<sub>2</sub> results in the cathodic peaks at 1.51, 1.75 and 2.05&nbsp;V <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. The above proposed sodium storage mechanism of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA could be concluded as follows (Eqs. 1–9) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>:</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr4.jpg" height="465" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (567KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (567KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724010610-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. Na-ion storage performances of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-Cu<sub>1.82</sub>Se@GA in the voltage range of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V (vs. Na<sup>+</sup><span>/Na): (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the first three cycles at 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>−1</sup>; (b) Charge-discharge profiles at 0.2 A/g; (c) Cycling stability at 0.2 A/g; (d) Rate capabilities from 0.1 A/g to 2.0 A/g; (e) Cycling stability at high rate of 1 A/g (The first three cycles were activated at 0.1 A/g.); (f) CV curves at different scan rates (from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>); (g) Plots of log (scan rate) vs log (peak current), calculated from CV curves; (h) Capacity contribution ratios at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>; (i) Contribution ratios between diffusion controlled and capacitive capacity.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">The discharge xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1251,410)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(14847,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(15847,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-78"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-65"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(973,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">o</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">→</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mo is="true">-</mo></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="e0045" class="formula"><span class="label">(9)</span><span is="true">-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="0.166667em"
